item.title: Kirby Air Riders Release Date Set for November, Tons of New Info Revealed
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo has revealed a ton of new information about upcoming racing sequel Kirby Air Riders, including when you can expect to play the game.

In a new Nintendo Direct presentation aired earlier today, Nintendo, along with Air Riders director (and Nintendo legend) Masahiro Sakurai, revealed that Kirby Air Riders will be launching exclusively on Nintendo Switch 2 on November 20th.

Along with revealing the release date, Sakurai and Nintendo also divulged lots of new info about Air Riders' gameplay mechanics, characters, and game modes, and it sounds like the game will boast Sakurai's usual maximalist design philosophy (which is definitely a good thing!).

Essentially, Air Riders takes the form of a sort of auto-racer; you won't need to press any buttons to accelerate, but you will need to perform maneuvers to outfox your opponents, use specials to gain advantages, and more.

Each rider has different stats; Kirby, for instance, has a different weight stat to King Dedede, who won't feel the same to play as Meta Knight. You'll need to weigh up which racer you want to use on which course if you want to win.

If you're a Kirby Air Ride fan, you'll probably recognize the returning City Trial mode, which has been expanded; it now takes place on a massive floating island by the name of Skyah, which is a free-roaming map packed with events to enjoy.

Of course, you'll also be able to take part in the game's titular Air Ride mode, which sees you and up to five other riders competing to cross the finish line, as well as other gameplay modes to try out.

Kirby Air Riders' release in November means it's one of two major Nintendo racing games to be released during the Switch 2's launch window, with the other naturally being the flagship launch game Mario Kart World.

In any case, Kirby Air Riders launches exclusively for Nintendo Switch 2 on November 20th. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Helldivers 2 Halo 3: ODST Collaboration Confirmed in Latest Warbond
item.content:encoded:
Sony and Xbox have confirmed that the teased Helldivers 2 Halo 3: ODST crossover is indeed real, and it's taking the form of the game's latest Warbond, which also happens to be its first "Legendary Warbond".

The crossover was first teased as part of a Helldivers 2 trailer promoting the game's Xbox release, which is set for next Tuesday. Rather than a new map or an in-game event, Helldivers 2's Halo 3: ODST crossover will instead take the form of a Warbond.

That means you can expect new weapons, new armor and capes, and all the other good stuff that usually comes with a Helldivers 2 Warbond, but as the "Legendary" designation suggests, Sony and Arrowhead reckon they're kicking it up a notch with this one.

This Warbond comes complete with four weapons, and they should all be pretty familiar to Halo fans. The MA5C assault rifle is an iconic weapon that packs an ammo counter and a compass, while the M6C pistol boasts Helldivers 2's first suppressor.

The M90A shotgun has a flashlight attached to it to help you see what you're shooting in darker areas, and the M7S SMG includes a suppressor you can't remove, so it's perfect for sneakier engagements (although it'll still rip enemies to shreds in a loud firefight).

Of course, it wouldn't be a Helldivers 2 Warbond if there wasn't some armor to enjoy as well, and the Halo 3: ODST Warbond features two sets: the A-9 Helljumper and the A-35 Recon, both modeled after iconic Halo 3: ODST characters.

There's plenty more included as part of this Warbond as well, so make sure you check out the full announcement over on the PlayStation Blog if you want to see everything that's included.

The Helldivers 2 Halo 3: ODST Warbond will be available on August 26th, which is the same day the game launches on Xbox Series X|S. It's also currently available on PC and PlayStation 5, and you can read our review of it right here.
